hedline.hl1: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Strikes Back At Protest Strikers

block.p: At least 200 people were injured in fighting today as the Government cracked down on the leaders of a protest campaign.
Clashes were reported in Dhaka, the capital; in the southeastern port city of Chittagong, and in four other cities on the second day of a three-day strike.
At least 200 people were injured in fighting today as the Government cracked down on the leaders of a protest campaign.
Clashes were reported in Dhaka, the capital; in the southeastern port city of Chittagong, and in four other cities on the second day of a three-day strike.
The crackdown was the first since three main opposition parties combined in 1994 in a campaign to unseat Prime Minister Khaleda Zia.

Three opposition leaders were arrested today and Saturday, the first sign of the tough stand Mrs. Zia had promised to take to end the frequent strikes. The opposition also boycotted a general election 10 days ago.
Normal life remained crippled. Sunday is a working day in predominantly Muslim Bangladesh, but trains were halted and schools and businesses closed.
The opposition wants Mrs. Zia to step down and let a neutral caretaker Government hold new elections.
